_accidents.CF_Other: Alternate electric power line down for maintenance
_accidents.CI_OtherType: Administrative controls for better communication from Power Supplier during their maintenance activities

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Risk Management Plan

INEOS - Chocolate Bayou Site

Executive Summary



The affiliated INEOS entities operating at the Chocolate Bayou Site are INEOS USA LLC and INEOS Oligomers LLC (collectively, hereinafter "INEOS"). The Chocolate Bayou Site is a stationary source subject to Clean Air Act Section 112r and 40 CFR 68.  The Chocolate Bayou Site may hereinafter be referred to as "Site" or "facility".  INEOS is committed to operating in a manner that is safe for our employees, the public, and the environment.  INEOS has established a system to ensure the safe operation of the processes at this facility as part of this commitment. Our RMP (Risk Management Program) is a part of this system that not only intends to manage the risks and/or hazards of our processes but also complies with the requirements of the Environmental Protection Agency's Regulation 40 ?CFR 68, Accidental Release Prevention Requirements: the RMP rule. This executive summary is to comply with the RMP Plan requirement of the RMP Rule (40 CFR ?68.150 through 40 CFR ?68.185).  



Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies  

INEOS is committed to the welfare of its employees, the public, and to the preservation of the environment. INEOS implements reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of hazardous substances. In the event of an accidental release, INEOS will conduct emergency response action to help prevent or minimize injury to the public and the environment.  



Description of Facility/Regulated substances handled

INEOS - Chocolate Bayou Site manufactures polypropylene plastic and olefins, including ethylene, propylene, and butadiene through the RMP processes 1 to 7, that are submitted in this RMP. These processes are operated by INEOS USA LLC. Twenty-seven different flammable substances are held over the threshold quantity. All are hydrocarbons, ranging from hydrogen to pentane. These are present at Site both in pure form and in mixtures. The site also has aqueous a

mmonia (conc. 20% or greater) that is considered a toxic substance. The aqueous ammonia inventory is over the threshold quantity.



This RMP Plan submission is to cover two changes that are taking place at the site: 



1.The addition of a new Steam and Power Cogeneration Plant within Process 7: C4(OLE1&2), operated by INEOS USA LLC.

      a.This addition is to upgrade power but does not affect inventory of stored chemicals within Process 7 or site.  Usage and handling of aqueous ammonia 

        is increased with this change, but the storage tank, and thus inventory of aqueous ammonia remain the same (aqueous ammonia inventory is contained 

        in Process 1). The planned date to start up this change in Process 7 is before 2019 is over (on or after July 2019).  This complies with RMP ?68.190

        (b)(5) "Within six months of a change that requires a revised PHA or hazard review".  Hazard Reviews have been completed prior to construction and 

        implementation of this change in the process and these will be incorporated to the C4 (OLE1&2) PHA/LOPAs. 



2.New Process that will be operating at the site (addition to existing RMP).

      a.New Process 8 - Linear Alpha Olefins Unit, operated by INEOS Oligomers USA LLC.  This unit/process is being incorporated to the RMP plan to comply 

        with ?68.190(b)(4) "No later than the date on which a regulated substance is first present above a threshold quantity in a new process".  This 

        unit/process will manufacture heavier olefins that range from 1-hexene (C6H2) to 1-tetracosene (C24H48).  This process will have three (3) flammable 

        substances: ethylene (no storage), 1-butene and propylene.  It is expected that on or after July 2019, Process 8 will have at least one of the 

        mentioned chemicals above the threshold.  



The Chocolate Bayou Site operates 24 hours a day, 365 days a year. The facility has management representation 24 hours a day through the presence of a shift su

perintendent (4) and several working team leaders. One of the superintendents (name, email, and phone number listed in the registration part of this submission) is the main Emergency Contact, but any of the other three (3) Shift Superintendents are trained and able to take in the Emergency Contact responsibilities within the RMP. The phone number for the emergency contact is the same for all Shift Superintendents as they share the same office.



Accidental Release Prevention Program:



1.Process Safety Information - The Chocolate Bayou Site maintains a variety of technical documents that are used to ensure the safe operation of the covered processes. SDS (Safety Data Sheets) document the physical properties of all hazardous substances handled in the site.  Engineering design documents include the safe operating parameters, design basis operating parameters, the design basis and configuration of the equipment of the covered process, and references to applicable codes and standards.  



2.Process Hazard Analysis - The Chocolate Bayou Site performs and updates risk assessments of the covered processes to ensure systematic identification and control of process hazards.  These risk evaluations include off-site consequences as well as possible environment consequence and public impact.  Processes 1 to 7 use the What-If/Checklist analysis technique along with the Layer of Protection (LOPA) Analysis technique to perform these hazards evaluations. Process 8 uses the HAZOP/LOPA methodology to evaluate the risks that might be associated with this particular process.



3.Operating Procedures - The Chocolate Bayou Site - Processes 1 to 7 maintains its operating procedures under the ISO9000 program.  As such, it is required to develop and maintain operating procedures to define how tasks related to process operation are performed.  Operating procedures are used to train employees and contractors and they also serve as reference guides for appropriate actions to take during no

rmal operations and process upsets. New Process 8 has developed specific operating procedures pertaining this new unit.



4.Training - To complement the written procedures for process operations, the Chocolate Bayou Site has implemented a comprehensive training program for all employees involved in operating a process. New employees receive basic training in chemical plant operations. After successfully completing this training, a new operator is paired with a senior operator to learn process-specific duties and tasks. After the new operator demonstrates (i.e. through tests, skills demonstration, etc.) having adequate knowledge to perform the duties and tasks in a safe manner on their own, they can work independently. In addition, all operators periodically receive refresher training on the operating procedures to ensure that their skills and knowledge are maintained at an acceptable level. This refresher training is conducted at least every three years. All of this training is documented, including the means used to verify that the operator understood the training. 



5.Mechanical Integrity - The Chocolate Bayou Site has well-established practices and procedures to maintain pressure vessels, piping systems, relief and vent systems, controls, pumps and compressors, and emergency shutdown systems in a safe operating condition. The basic aspects of this program include: (1) conducting training, (2) developing written procedures and plans, (3) performing inspections and tests, (4) correcting identified deficiencies, and (5) applying quality assurance measures.  These activities make up a system that maintains the integrity of the process equipment.



6.Management of Change (MOC) - The Chocolate Bayou Site utilizes a change management tool to ensure proper reviews are conducted, hazards are assessed, and a safe operation environment is maintained during and after the introduction of a change in the covered processes.  Each MOC (permanent or temporary) includes a risk

assessment to identify potential hazards of a change such as (1) process equipment, (2) chemicals, (4) technology (including process operating conditions), and other facility changes.  The MOC system ensures that all documentation is updated and training completed prior to the commissioning of the change.  Approval and action items are tracked in the MOC application.



7.Pre-Startup Safety Reviews (PSSRs) - The Chocolate Bayou Site conducts a PSSR for any new or modified facility that requires a change in the process safety information. This review confirms that (1) proper equipment is used, (2) that safety, operating, maintenance, and emergency procedures are updated, (3) a risk assessment is conducted and (4) training has been implemented. A PSSR involves field verification of the construction and serves a quality assurance function by requiring verification that accident prevention program requirements are properly implemented.



8.Compliance Audits - The Chocolate Bayou Site performs PSM and RMP compliance audits at least every three (3) years. Corrective actions taken in response to the audit team's findings are tracked until they are completed. The final resolution of each finding is documented, and the two most recent audit reports along with the resolution of findings are retained.



9.Incident Investigation - The Chocolate Bayou Site investigates all incidents that reasonably could have resulted in a serious injury to personnel, the public, or the environment.  The incident investigation procedure requires an investigation is initiated within 48 hours of the incident. The goal of each investigation is to determine the facts, identify the root cause and develop corrective actions to prevent a recurrence of the incident or a similar incident. The investigation team documents its findings, develops recommendations to prevent a recurrence, and forwards results to management for resolution. Corrective actions taken in response to the investigation team's fin

dings and recommendations are tracked until they are complete. The final resolution of each finding or recommendation is documented, and the investigation results are reviewed with all employees (including contractors) who could be affected by the findings. Incident investigation reports are retained for at least 5 years, so that the reports can be reviewed during future PHAs and PHA revalidations.



10.Employee Participation - The Chocolate Bayou Site encourages employees to participate in all facets of process safety management and accident prevention.  Our Site promotes employee participation through different established safety programs: VPP (Voluntary Protection Program), ESALT (Employee Safety Action and Leadership Team), PSC (Process Safety Committee), ERT (Emergency Response Team) amongst others.  Other examples of employee participation range from updating and compiling technical information to participating as a member of a process hazard analysis (PHA) team and incident investigation teams. Employees have access to all information created as part of the Site prevention program. Specific ways that employees can be involved in the prevention program are documented in the employee participation plan that addresses each prevention program element. 



11.Hot Work Permit - The Chocolate Bayou Site mitigates hot work hazards with a Safe Work Permitting Processes.



12.Contractors - The Chocolate Bayou Site uses contractors to supplement its work force during periods of increased maintenance or construction activities. Because some contractors work on or near process equipment, the Site has procedures in place to ensure that contractors (1) perform their work in a safe manner, (2) have the appropriate knowledge and skills, (3) are aware of the hazards in their workplace, (4) understand what they should do in the event of an emergency, (5) understand and follow site safety rules, and (6) inform Site personnel of any hazards that they find during their work. Thi

s is accomplished by providing contractors with (1) a process overview, (2) information about safety and health hazards, (3) emergency response plan requirements, and (4) safe work practices prior to start working. The Site evaluates contractor safety programs and performance during the selection of a contractor. Site personnel periodically monitor contractor performance to ensure that contractors are fulfilling their safety obligations. 



Emergency Response

The Chocolate Bayou Site has a written emergency response plan that complies with the RMP Rule and other federal contingency plans.   The site has its own volunteer fire brigade to respond to emergencies. Personnel receive training in responding to industrial fires and other emergencies. The facility periodically conducts drills of our emergency response system.  Emergency response is also coordinated with the LEPC.



Five-year accident history

The Site has had one accidental release as defined by the RMP regulation in the past 5 years. An accidental release of flammable materials mainly through the flares occurred on 09-18-15. The initiating event was a power loss to the facility due to fault in the electricity grid; the equipment failure was external to the site.  The contributing factor was that power failure occurred at a time when alternate electric power line to the site was out of service for scheduled maintenance.  The on-site impact was significant property damage due to the forced shutdown of operating equipment. There were no offsite impacts as defined by the RMP regulation.



Planned changes to improve safety

Fire Pumps were replaced or upgraded since last submission.   Improvement in safety continues from our hazard identification system: PHA, incident investigations, audits, employee input, and from lessons learned within INEOS and similar industries.
